newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: LME copper seen up, trade mulls S'pore zinc levels.
newsitem.headline: LME copper seen up, trade mulls S'pore zinc levels.

text.p: London Metal Exchange (LME) copper prices are seen making a fresh tentative stab at the elusive US$2,500 mark later on Tuesday, base metal dealers said.
"I still think it will make a try at $2,500," a dealer for a foreign metal trading company in Singapore said.
"It should go up a bit on some shortcovering this afternoon," the general manager of another firm said, adding he expected cash copper prices to gain about $20 on the LME.
Three-month copper was quoted by the trade at around $2,491/96 a tonne at 0230 GMT, little changed from the late indication in London on Monday of $2,490/96 a tonne.
"With very little interest noted, prices drifted in a tight 11 dollar range, lacking any real direction," brokers Macquarie said in their daily review.
Far East dealers said another projected copper stock draw, when the LME report comes out at 0800 GMT, should provide short-term direction for the market.
LME brokers Brandeis said the low level of copper stocks and supply worries "should favour the upside in the short-term."

"With the 10-day moving average now falling towards current price levels, it would not be surprising to see the market attempting to get above this level so as to spur technical buying," Brandeis said.
The base metal business in the region was quiet with the trade mulling the actual volume of Chinese zinc said to be in warehouses in Singapore.
"Rumours are still going around about huge zinc parcels coming in," a dealer said.
But another dealer said problems in getting export licences in China may keep zinc from being shipped to the city-state.
"I don't think fresh zinc will be coming here," he said.
The volume of zinc in the LME's Singapore warehouse reached 20,650 tonnes on Monday, down 575 tonnes from last Friday's level. Dealers estimate about 20,000 tonnes of zinc remain off-warrant here.
